draft:
Is temporary blockage of blood flow to a distant part of the body (remote ischaemic preconditioning) beneficial compared with no blockage for people undergoing major blood‑vessel surgery?

Key messages  
– Remote ischaemic preconditioning (RIPC), a brief, harmless blockage of blood flow to an arm or leg, probably does not change the risk of death around the time of surgery, heart attack, kidney problems, stroke, loss of a limb, length of hospital stay, or the time the operation takes.  
– The 14 trials we examined were of moderate quality, so we cannot completely rule out small benefits or harms.  
– Larger, well‑designed trials are needed to find out whether RIPC offers any real advantage for patients having major vascular or endovascular surgery.

What health problems are associated with major vascular and endovascular surgery?  
People who need major operations on large blood vessels – such as repairing an aortic aneurysm or opening blocked arteries – face serious complications. Even with modern care, they can experience death (mortality) or major health problems after the operation. Common complications include heart attacks (damage to the heart muscle), kidney problems (when the kidneys do not work well), strokes (brain damage from interrupted blood flow), loss of a limb, and longer stays in hospital.

What is remote ischaemic preconditioning and why might it help?  
Remote ischaemic preconditioning (RIPC) is a technique where we briefly stop blood flow to a part of the body that is not being operated on, using a blood‑pressure cuff on an arm or leg. This short, controlled blockage is thought to “train” the body’s cells to survive longer periods of reduced blood flow (ischaemia) that can occur during surgery. In simple terms, it gives the body a tiny stress so that it can protect its organs when a bigger stress happens during the operation.

What did the researchers want to find out?  
We set out to discover whether using RIPC before elective (planned) major vascular or endovascular surgery makes a difference compared with not using it. Specifically, we wanted to know if RIPC reduces the risk of death around the time of surgery, heart attacks, kidney problems, strokes, loss of a limb, length of hospital stay, and the time needed for the operation or anaesthesia. We also looked for any harms.

How did we find the evidence?  
We searched several databases for randomised controlled trials that compared RIPC with no preconditioning in people undergoing elective major vascular or endovascular surgery. We combined the results using a statistical method that looks at differences between studies, and we assessed how sure we are about the evidence using a standard grading system (GRADE) that rates confidence as low, moderate, or high.

What did we find?  
We identified 14 trials that together enrolled 1,295 participants (average age 64.5–76 years; 84 % men). All trials compared a short, reversible interruption of blood flow to a limb with no preconditioning. The pooled results suggest that RIPC probably makes little or no difference to any of the main outcomes after surgery. It did not clearly change the risk of death around the time of surgery (peri‑operative death), heart attack, kidney problems, stroke, or loss of a limb. It also did not affect how long people stayed in hospital or how long the operation or anaesthetic took.

What are the limitations of the evidence?  
We are moderately confident in these findings. This is because only a few studies were available, the participants and the way RIPC was given differed between studies, and the small number of trials might make the benefits look larger than they really are.

How current is the evidence?  
This review updates our previous work and includes all relevant studies up to April 2022.

evaluation.feedback: The draft fails the clarity check for a patient‑focused Plain Language Summary. Three or more significant issues were found that would likely confuse readers: (1) technical jargon such as “randomised controlled trials” and “GRADE” is not explained; (2) a long, complex sentence in the Methods section obscures meaning; (3) the first key‑message bullet crams seven outcomes into one dense sentence, making it hard to follow; (4) the Results paragraph still uses the term “peri‑operative death” and parentheses that add unnecessary complexity; (5) the statement “We are moderately confident” is vague for a lay audience. These issues are reflected in the metric analysis, which shows unusually high noun count (182 vs typical <116) and high numbers of complex words (248 DC words, 118 polysyllabic words). Reducing noun density and simplifying vocabulary will improve readability. Suggested rewrites are provided for each quoted problem in the detailed review.
evaluation.pls_evaluation_summary: The PLS evaluation shows the draft conforms overall to typical patterns, but three metrics deviate: nouns (182, P90), complex_words_dc (248, P90) and complex_words (118, P90). These indicate the text is noun‑heavy and uses many difficult words, supporting the need to simplify language and reduce noun density.
